title: Flooding & Overwhelm
description: Explore how you experience and manage feeling overwhelmed during conflict.

questions.text: During intense conflict, I sometimes experience...
choices: Racing heart, tension, or physical stress
Difficulty thinking clearly or finding words
An urge to escape or shut down
All of these—conflict overwhelms my system

therapeutic.rationale: Flooding is a physiological state where conflict overwhelms your nervous system. Physical symptoms, cognitive impairment, and escape urges are common signs. When flooded, productive conversation is impossible.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different flooding experiences are all valid. The person who doesn't flood may not understand their partner's overwhelm. Both need to recognize flooding when it happens.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared flooding experience creates mutual understanding of how conflict affects you both.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What happens in your body during intense conflict? How do you know when you're overwhelmed?

questions.text: When I'm getting overwhelmed in a conflict, I need to...
choices: Take a break and calm down
Slow things down and breathe
Ask my partner to speak more softly
Push through—stopping feels like avoiding

therapeutic.rationale: Flooding responses matter. Breaks allow nervous system recovery; slowing down helps regulation; asking for softer speech sets limits; pushing through often backfires—flooded people can't be productive. Knowing your need helps.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different responses need different partner support. The break-needer may need permission to pause; the push-through type may need encouragement to take breaks.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared flooding response creates aligned expectations about managing overwhelm.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What helps you when you're overwhelmed in conflict? What makes it worse?

questions.text: When my partner seems overwhelmed during conflict, I try to...
choices: Soften my approach and slow down
Suggest we take a break
Give them space to regulate
I sometimes don't notice until too late

therapeutic.rationale: Noticing partner flooding prevents escalation. Softening helps; break suggestions help; space helps; not noticing allows harm. Learning your partner's flooding signals—and responding—is a crucial skill.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different approaches can all help. The key is noticing and responding, not the specific response.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared approach to partner overwhelm creates mutual care during conflict.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you notice when your partner is getting overwhelmed? What do you do?

questions.text: Taking a break during conflict feels...
choices: Necessary and healthy
Like avoiding or giving up
Difficult but sometimes needed
Depends on whether we agree to return

therapeutic.rationale: Break attitudes affect whether breaks happen. Those who see breaks as healthy use them well; those who see avoidance may push through flooding; difficulty accepters are conflicted; return-conditioners have appropriate concerns.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The break-positive partner may feel the break-resistant partner won't let them regulate; the break-resistant partner may feel abandoned. Agree on break protocols in advance.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared break attitudes make using breaks natural and non-threatening.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you feel about taking breaks during conflict? What would make breaks work better?

questions.text: A healthy break during conflict would include...
choices: Agreeing on when we'll return to talk
Self-soothing rather than rehearsing arguments
Trusting the break isn't abandonment
All of these—breaks need structure

therapeutic.rationale: Effective breaks have structure. Return agreements prevent indefinite avoidance; self-soothing (not ruminating) allows recovery; trust prevents attachment anxiety. Gottman recommends at least 20 minutes for physiological calm.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: All these elements help breaks work. Discuss what you each need for breaks to feel safe.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared break structure creates clear expectations that make breaks productive.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What would make breaks during conflict feel safe and productive for you?
